If you are looking for work-study options, there are a number of options available. Here are some of the most popular:


Find a job.  Many states and localities have offered job openings to people looking to start a new job in the coming weeks or months. Some companies are offering full-time positions, but many of these positions are temporary and can be filled by workers who have already been laid off or have been placed back on the job market. Employers are also offering paid sick leave and paid family leave, as well as paid leave to employees who are out of work due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Many state, local, and tribal governments have set aside money to help pay for essential needs, such as food stamps and unemployment insurance, for people who need them most. But many states have closed or suspended their unemployment programs, so you may be able to find work through your local job training program, which requires you to submit an application online and provide proof of income, including Social Security numbers, driver's license, health insurance number, medical certificate, child care card, or a government-issued ID card. For information on how to file your own tax return, see How can I file my own return?. If your child’s school or college graduation is delayed or canceled, the government may provide financial assistance, though it is not guaranteed that it will be sufficient to cover the costs of paying for college and graduate school expenses. In some states, schools and universities have canceled or reduced classes, leaving students with little or no income to rely on for their education. To find out if you qualify for help with your taxes, call your [state or county](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/help-with-your- taxes) or call the [State and County] Office of Emergency Services at 1-800-662-4000. It’s hard to know exactly how long a virus can survive on a surface, but scientists say that it could be up to two weeks. 
 Scientists at the University of Rochester Medical Center in Rochester, New York, say they have found a way to make a vaccine that lasts longer on plastic and stainless steel than on cardboard.
“If you put a piece of plastic on it, it will stick to the surface for a long time,” said Dr. William Schaffner, a professor of microbiology and immunology at Rochester College of Medicine. “So if you take it out of a plastic bag and put it in a container and let it air dry, you can see it sticking to surfaces for days. And then you have to start looking at it again and again to see if it has developed immunity to other coronaviruses that are on the market right now. So it is a very, very long-lasting vaccine, and we are very hopeful that we will be able to get it into human clinical trials in the next couple of months. We are also looking for other ways to extend the life of the vaccine."
 The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to be spread primarily through respiratory droplets produced when someone coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted through contact with bodily fluids, such as saliva or mucus, which can cause symptoms similar to those caused by the common cold. But scientists are still trying to figure out if there are any biological mechanisms that could prevent or cure the disease.


So far, no vaccine has been developed to protect against the illness. However, there have been a number of studies that have shown that certain types of vaccines can be effective against certain viruses. For example, the flu shot was shown to have antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2, while the hepatitis C vaccine had anti-HIV-1 antibody against MERS and the influenza vaccine against H1N1. The most recent study, published in JAMA Pediatrics on March 27, found that a combination of routine hand hygiene and routine use of hand sanitizer significantly reduced the risk of developing severe illness in infants born to mothers who had been exposed to at least one other person who tested positive for the viruses, compared with those who did not wear any personal protective equipment (PPE).

The CDC recommends that people wear a cloth face covering when handling small amounts of household items, like wipes and disinfecting surfaces with household disinfectants. (The bottom line is that if you are covered by an insurance policy, you have the right to sue your employer for wrongful termination, and you should be able to get a $100,000 wrongful-death award.  If you lost your job because of your coverage, the government will probably have to pay you back at least a portion of that amount, which is a lot of money for a small business. But that's not the whole story, of course. The government can't just throw money at you and say, "Go back to work and get your money back," and then demand that you pay back whatever you owe them. So the best way to protect yourself and your family from this is to have a plan in place that covers all your expenses, including your insurance premiums, deductibles, co-payments, car payments, medical bills, rent, utilities, child care, groceries, etc. You can find a list of state and local government agencies that are working on this, but they are not all in the same place, so it's best to go to a local agency and ask for help, rather than going to the state or local sheriff's office to find out if there are any local law enforcement agencies you can call to help with your case. If there aren't any, call your state attorney general and request that he or she designate a special prosecutor to look into your situation and make sure there is no abuse of office or corruption of justice that could put you in jail for life. This is especially important in states that have been hit hard by the outbreak, like New York and California, where the number of people who have died has doubled every year since the beginning of the epidemic. It is also important to remember that the federal government has the authority to take punitive actions against states and municipalities that fail to provide essential services to their citizens, even if the people in those states are in violation of federal law. For example, if a state government employee is found to be negligent in its response to Hurricane Harvey relief efforts, they could face up to 10 years in prison and a hefty fine, though that is not a punishment that can be used to punish a person for not doing their part in helping to prop up the flood-ravaged state. In general, it is better to stay home and do your own research before making a decision to leave your home, especially if your loved one is in need of urgent care or is being cared for by a health care provider who is willing to treat you like any other human being, whether that be a paramedic, an emergency room physician, a mental health provider, someone with a proven history of mental illness or a family member who has been in close contact with the person who needs to care for the sick person, to ensure that they do not end up in isolation or in an institution where they may be at higher risk for severe illness and/or for other serious health conditions, such as heart disease, stroke, cancer, diabetes, heart failure, lung disease or lung cancer. Be sure to self-isolate, wash your hands frequently and thoroughly with soap and water, avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth, cover your cough and sneeze with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer or hand rub and maintain a distance of 1 meter (3 feet) from others who are coughing, sneezing or touching you.

The current coronavirus pandemic has infected more people than the entire world combined, according to the World Health Organization.

The WHO says that the number of people who have died from COVID-19 in the United States is estimated at more than 1.5 billion. That's a death rate of about 1 in every 1,000 people, or about 0.2 per cent of the world's population. The WHO estimates the mortality rate for the disease at about 3.6 per 100, 100 and 200 people respectively, depending on age, health conditions, geographic location and other factors, and it’s not known how many of those people will develop severe illness.


So far, the WHO has not published a complete list of affected countries, but it does include countries that have been hit hard by the outbreak, such as Iran, Sierra Leone, Nepal, South Korea, China and the Philippines. It also includes countries with relatively mild disease outbreaks like the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, which has killed between 1 and 2 million people and caused about $700 billion in economic and social damage, as well as the deaths of hundreds of thousands of other people in China, India, Iran and Nepal.  
 But WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said the organization is still assessing the situation and will update as more information becomes available. He did not elaborate on the specific countries affected, other than to say that it is "very likely" that at least some of these countries will experience some degree of economic or social disruption, including the loss of essential services like healthcare, schools, healthcare facilities and public health services. WHO is also working with local partners to develop a plan for how to best protect people living with HIV and those who may be at higher risk for severe disease, like those with underlying medical conditions or people with preexisting conditions. For example, if you are coughing and sneezing, your body recognizes the cough as a sign of illness and will try to treat it as soon as possible. If you develop fever, cough and difficulty breathing, the next time you feel unwell, seek medical attention and call in advance to arrange a time and place for yourself to be isolated and cared for. This is especially important for people who are immunocompromised and who may be at higher risk for severe illness, such as those with underlying medical conditions or those who have been in close contact with people with the disease. For people living with HIV, for whom self-isolation is a possibility, isolation can be an effective way to protect them and their loved ones from further spread of the virus. However, it is important to remember that isolation does not necessarily mean that you will be quarantined or placed in isolation, as some people do develop symptoms and require further treatment. In general, people should continue to practice good respiratory hygiene and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from people they are close to, including their pets and other close family members. You should also wash your hands frequently with soap and water and avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth. Follow the directions of your local health authority and local authorities for any restrictions on travel, movement or movement of people in and around your country.
